DrD

The only thing Wednesday's gatherings have in common with the 1773 Boston Tea Party is anger.
 
 But in Boston in 1773, the people were angry because they were being taxed and had no voice in the government levying those taxes. No one should be taxed by a government that denies them a voice.
 
 The British government took no heed of their anger, thus setting off what would become the fight for American independence. We won the right to peaceably gather and petition our government for redress of grievances.
 The original partygoers had a singular focus. They started an organized fight, and they won.
 
 In the modern-day tea parties that happened all over the country Wednesday night, however, the people who gathered were angry in general, not angry at anything specific. They were angry for all kinds of reasons: Taxes are too high. Congress is spending too much money. States are letting gay people get married. "The media" mistreated Sarah Palin. Abortion is immoral. We're leaving Iraq. Their candidate lost. These grassroots were really individual plants, each clinging to a different grain of anger.
 
 When real, focused grassroots efforts take hold, the people's voices are most important. But grass needs firm soil in which to grow.
 
 We all are anxious about the situation in which our nation finds itself. Some are worried about the direction it's headed. And some on the fringe seek to capitalize on the anxiety of others.
 
 The modern-day tea parties were drummed up by ultra-conservative commentators. Preying on average people's fears, they fan flames of anxiety and cast blame on President Obama and the Democratic Party. These were conservative Republican rallies in all but name.
 
 The rational voice of the average, concerned resident can be lost in the din of partisan bashing.
 
 We all want fair taxes.
 
 We all want elected officials to hear us.
 
 With all the challenges facing us, our best hope is in the spirit of democracy, in our ability to comprehend those challenges and openly debate the best ways to overcome them. There is no room for paralyzing fear - or calls to just say "no" to anything and everything.
 
 We must remain involved in the political process by speaking out - all of us. To do otherwise is to let those on either extreme steer our nation.
 
 We need discussion, not slogans, and deep-rooted ideas fairly debated. Then we'll be true to the roots put down by those real tea partiers long ago.
 
 Opinions expressed in this article represent the majority opinion of the newspaper's editorial board, consisting of: Roger Watson, president and publisher; David Fritz, executive editor; Cindy Corell, community conversations editor; and Jim McCloskey, editorial cartoonist.

The Boston Tea Party, 1773, came out of a long-standing dispute with the East India Company over a corporate monopoly on the tea supplied to the colonies:
 
As Europeans developed a taste for tea in the 17th century, rival companies were formed to import the product from the East Indies. In England, Parliament gave the East India Company a monopoly on the importation of tea in 1698. When tea became popular in the British colonies, Parliament sought to eliminate foreign competition by passing an act in 1721 that required colonists to import their tea only from Great Britain. The East India Company did not export tea to the colonies; by law, the company was required to sell its tea wholesale at auctions in England. British firms bought this tea and exported it to the colonies, where they resold it to merchants in Boston, New York, Philadelphia, and Charleston.

 Boston Tea Party - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 They were also revolting against taxation without representation:
 
Colonists objected to the Tea Act for a variety of reasons, especially because they believed that it violated their constitutional right to be taxed only by their own elected representatives. Protestors had successfully prevented the unloading of taxed tea in three other colonies, but in Boston, embattled Royal Governor Thomas Hutchinson refused to allow the tea to be returned to Britain.
